title: Auggie's Flippable iPhone 7 PLUS, 6 PLUS or 6S PLUS cradle with sound redirector amplifier Landscape and Portrait Modes
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Auggie's Flippable iPhone 7 PLUS, 6 PLUS or 6S PLUS cradle with sound redirector amplifier Landscape and Portrait Modes

This one I truly love. It's is a different and more useful take on my previous designs. The need for it came to me when I kept looking at Facebook and realizing that since the Facebook timeline doesn't have a landscape mode I kept switching the portrait to landscape and back all the time while on the Facebook app when I wanted to watch a video.

Works both with or without cases up to 9.3 mm thick. It allows the user to watch movies while resting in bed with the sound redirected forward toward the user or for watching videos while having breakfast on a table. It also allows for browsing in portrait mode as when browsing Facebook and still allows for charging and headphones if wanted.

It includes the hole for the 6 plus and the %S plus 3.5mm jack. It also works as a night table cradle to recharge overnight and to use alarm clock apps in either landscape or portrait modes.

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

title: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus - Logitech C920 Webcam - Mount

description.text:
Update (8/20/2017): After a couple of weeks of use, I'm thinking that I can't recommend this design. It works for my needs (monitoring the print), but it didn't take long to loosen enough that there is a lot of jerk in the mount during prints which means that the feed is blurs every time the y axis changes direction. It still does the job for me, but there are probably better camera mounts out there.

A bed-mounted webcam mount for the Logitech C920 camera on the Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus. Allows for objects to be stationary in frame when doing timelapses.

This mount requires loosening of the bed by a few millimeters in order to get mounted, but it just slides right on and stays in place really well. Requires a 1/4" screw on the bottom, but that screw also holds the two separate pieces together. Assembly is really easy once you slide the pieces onto the undercarriage of the print bed.

title: 50mm STI Reverse Lockout Shift Knob Remix

description.text:
FILE RECOMMENDED FOR FDM:
Please use the adjusted sleeve files when printing with an FDM printer. They will generally let the nut slip in better and put less stress on the part. The other adjusted part may work as well but it usually isn't as easy to use. Thanks for downloading!

UPDATE
Shrinkage became an issue when making this project on FDM printers. New models have been added as a result. The sleeve adjusted models have an additional 0.4mm added to the diameter of the hex nut of the already adjusted models for ease of installation but may require epoxy when printing. The plainly adjusted models however, are built with a 1 mm adjustment to allow for shrinkage to not be an issue. Please use either of these shrink adjusted top and bottom files for better results and easier assembly if using a FDM printer.

If you want a 60mm version instead of a 50mm version of this please go to my other design here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2467630

This is the smaller version of a previous design that I based off of the remix of the WRX Shift Knob originally created by WillsWorld and remixed by Dingoboy71. This design incorporates the reverse lockout design meant for STIs while being at a 50mm diameter. I used Fusion 360 as well as hand measurements off of the original print to redesign this by handing customize it to my liking.

Changes:
Changed the logo to be the STI logo and altered the position of the hex nut to be between both the top and bottom pieces to improve strength.

Purchase the hardware that is required below and put it together!

Hardware required:
(1) m12 x 1.25 thread pitch Nylock nut.
(6) m3 x 20 (or 25) mm hex bolts
(6) m3 x .5mm Nylock nuts.
(1) Tube of super glue or epoxy.

*Nylock nuts recommended are recommended by Dingoboy71. It is stated that you could use Loc-Tite but he recommends that you pay close attention to choosing the right variant or else you may permanently weld [it] to your car."

description.text: This is a frame for Hexa copter using 8mm brushed motors.

This is a simple object for interrogating the dimensional accuracy of your printer. I accept 1 layer height of variation as being within the acceptable range (e.g. ± 0.20 mm).

It takes about 12 minutes to print at 70 mm/s, 0.40 mm nozzle, 0.2 mm layer height.

Dimensional accuracy is less important than getting enough plastic down. Calibrate your flow rate correctly to figure this out.

An extruder mount replacement for the plain vanilla prointrbit (not LC) which includes a 40mm fan mount. It is a two part device which is box like with a 32mm opening at the bottom for the printer nozzle and airflow. Initial versions had the fan sloping 25 deg so it could be used without the "lid" part but this is difficult to 3D print.
I have included the orginal in the SU file but not posted .stl for them ATM. The design is a bit heavier than it needs to be. It is possible heat build up could be problem if the fan is off for extened periods with the hotend hot. The thing doesn't need to be air tight so extra ventilation holes could be added. The fan worked too well and I had to partly cover the intake to tame it down.
Some tuning it likely for changes in room temperature, filament, layer height and the size of the print.

Can be 3D printed on printrbot.
The small screwholes are intended to be tapped to M3 but the holes may print too large on some printers and need bigger screws or filling in in some way. The cable access hole has bit of support material which needs to be removed - be careful with this - if you use side cutters you may crack the main shell (I did) - try to twist it out with pointy pliers.
The lid part would probably hold on just fine using a rubber band.
It is mounted the same way as the orginal part. Test patterns such as the one shown in the image can be found here.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:23965

Total cost like $50

The code is pretty basic.

The battery lasts 7+ hours and probably could be increased a lot with some tricks to save power.

title: Prusa i3 MK2S X-axis adjustable idler

description.text:
There have been reports of the x-axis belt getting worn by the x-axis idler pulley on Prusa i3 MK2s printers. Happened to me. Looked for a decent solution but didn't see one. So I remixed the Prusa x-axis idler.

I wanted something that would work without purchasing any weird metric nuts and bolts cause there aren't any decent hardware stores where I live. Luckily Prusa ships a box of spare parts, including two long bolts and two self-locking nuts. So I used them to create what you see. By slowly adjusting the bolts in and out you can shift the x-axis idler pulley just enough to reduce or eliminate that black dust that used to be your belt. I printed mine in white ABS just to be sure to see any dust. So far, so clean.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.15 or .20

Infill:

50%

Notes:

In your slicer program (I'm using Slic3r) you must check 'detect thin walls' or Slic3r will NOT print the very thin support material which is integrated into the .stl file.

After printing the x-axis-idler3 you must remove the support material where the x-axis-adjuster2 goes.

When assembling, don't tighten the x-axis idler pulley axle too tight or the pulley will not be able to twist slightly off axis to relieve belt wear. I left about a playing card width of wiggle room.

title: 3D PRINT READY!! Yang Xiao Long from RWBY

description.text:
This print is ready to go and does not need any more fixing to be printed!

3D Print other RWBY models here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2357481 Ruby Rose
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2397963 Weiss Schnee
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2447958 Blake Belladonna

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2504153 Velvet
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2753068 Nora

Join the Anime Figure group and share and print anime figures! As well as Updates on what im doing next https://www.thingiverse.com/groups/animefigures
Support me on Patreon! https://www.patreon.com/AnimuAnimu/posts

This print already has all the support material ready to go, DO NOT add SUPPORT MATERIAL.
the support material that i already added to the file has tapered ends and easily breaks off, however be very careful removing, especially around the head. no cutting or gluing necessary.
Print with AT LEAST 30% infill and be careful removing supports, there are many fragile features.
DO NOT PRINT WITH A RAFT OR SUPPORT MATERIAL
as you can see in the images, part of my support material failed while printing because i bumped the printer, do not freak out of the supports fail mid print, they are mostly redundent and designed to recover.

there are TWO stl files included, PRINT THE 3DPrintReady FILE. I included files of the print without supports if you want to add your own supports. note a base is necessary or the model will tip over.

print this at .1mm layer height for optimal results.

i did a bunch of smoothing in Meshmixer, so the stl file is quite big even after being 'reduced' so be patient!

Im working on making the whole RWBY gang, but my job is sucking all my time and on top of that meshmixer keeps crashing so be patient! these things a pain to get printable

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1 mm layer height for best results

Infill:

30% this is critical that you make it at least 30 percent

Notes:

I printed this on a monoprice maker select plus (a rebrand of the wanhao, identical printer)
if you want to speed up print time, keep the outer layer slow, so it looks good, but increase the fill print speed.

IMPORTANT: you MUST have AT LEAST a .8mm shell thickness or the supports will fuse with the model! (need the model to be strong enough that when the supports are removed they dont take some of the model with them)

for scale, the model is ~115mm tall including base (4.53 in) i would strongly recommend not printing this any smaller, there are already very small and fragile features as it is. i can make a version with thicker supports so it can be printed smaller if requested, but it may take me some time to get to it.
just a pliers and a flush cut to remove any stringing and the break-away supports. be careful removing supports, the model has many detailed and thin features. especially with the hair

this is a scan of an MMD model that posed and edited and made print ready with pmx editor and meshmixer. i also did a lot of smoothing, the scan had sharp polynomials and edges. The hair was a mess to fix, and lots of work in meshmixer was required. i spent a solid 8 hrs working on this model.
consider donating please, it really helps me stay motivated to keep spending the time to take pictures and post these :) thanks

comments.text: From the looks I assume the supports are from Meshmixer. Just out of curiosity, how much of them was auto-generated and how much did you add/edit manually? I'm planning on adding supports to some of my 3d models so that they become printable, but sometimes I find the supports generated by Meshmixer to be rather sketchy, like very long lines at 45-55° angles without any support.
comments.author: Noisyedge

comments.text:
yes they are meshmixer generated. i find that about 4 mm thick and .5 to .75 mm diameter tips work best.
the generate support button really is not all that smart, but is good for getting a rough skeleton. it likes to follow the contours of the design a lot, which you will have to change to avoid having a tube fused to the model.
once i generate supports, i go around deleting the bad ones, with a Ctrl click i think, and then adding new ones where it needs, often adding lots of redundancies because it generates them pretty sparsely. you can click a red overhang for it to try to generate a support at that spot, but a click and drag works better. holding shift or Ctrl overrides collisions, which is often an issue when trying to manually add them.
then once you make solid the supports, go back in with the sculpt tool and fix it, round out some awkward connections, and make sure parts are not touching where you dont want them too.
it usually takes me at least one or two missprints to fully get the supports right.
meshmixer supports are a lot more fussy than just grid style ones, but it is a world of difference when cleaning up a model. being able to just break off a cylinder vs going in with an Xacto blade removing the fused grid from a detailed part. they are not even in the same ballpark in comparison.

The stock rubber pads for the MP Delta are only about 4mm tall. I wanted something a little taller for better airflow underneath especially if I add a fan in the base. These bolt up in existing holes. You could probably reuse existing screws, but I swapped in M3x8mm hex heads in place.

For the rubber feet I had some leftover 21mmx15mmx11.5mm tall feet with some M5x8mm screws and a square nut that slides into a holder in the foot. This adds about 21mm clearance for a whole inch below open area.

I also have a version with a couple of slots where you can zip tie up the power or USB cords to provide strain relief. With the power connector attached directly to the control board I was a little concerned about possibly damaging it if I drop the power adapter or something

I made this on my Anet A8 but they will fit on the delta itself also

title: Remixed Adjustable Spool Holder - ALunar (Prusa Clone)

description.text:
i remixed the roller bearing spool holder to add a mountable bracketfor my ALunar Printer. The design uses existing mounting hardware from the printer as well as extra parts from the kit.

The little "adapters" are there because I screwed up and printed the spool plate without changing the holes sizes. I already printed it so I just made adapters. You can fix the sketch-up model to suit your screw and nut sizes.

The spool holder uses those skateboard bearings ( 608 i think).

I added the filament guide later...but I never re-printed it. I have not had any issues with feeding now and I've used a few different spools. The bottom of the second half uses two O-rings ( not really necessary I think) as the original design was so well made, the friction keeps them from moving under vibration.

i hope this remix helps as my machine now feeds from the top down.

I added a "Together" file so you can see how everything fits together.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

20+

Notes:

You can print at a higher resolution, but 2mm was fine. The infill I think I used 20% and I think it's fine. You might need to sand the bearing knobs a little so pressing the bearings on would be easier and avoid nub breakage. I broke one but i super glued it and it's been fine since.

This is a standard size 6" x 16" CMU (Concrete Masonry Unit)

I modeled it at 1:1 scale so you'll have to scale it down when you print it, or you'll end up with a HUGE print on your hands.

It was modeled after the specs shown in a PDF from specblockusa.com:
http://specblockusa.com/downloads/gray-block/size-shape-2013.pdf

The actual modeled dimensions are 5 5/8" x 5 5/8" x 15 5/8" which is the actual size of a concrete CMU (3/8th" is left out for mortar)

This is the Hera CQR stock for M-4/AR-15 pattern AEG airsoft rifles. The design is not 100% the same as the real-steel version as the pistol grip has to house the motor. The measurements for the interface are from the lancer tactical LT-12, this may not fit your gun exactly, however, it should fit most.

ASSEMBLY:
-Remove the stock, motor, and pistol grip from your current gun. Set aside the screws used to secure the pistol grip to the gearbox, as well as the endcap/radiator for the motor, these will be used later.
-Slide the stock onto your gun's buffer tube, before it is slid completely on, route the motor wires through the holes in the grip-section.
-Once the stock is slid all the way down, use the screw you set aside earlier to affix the grip to the gearbox.
-Next insert the Body retaining pin (or a similarly-sized pin) into the hole near the base of the buffer tube.
-Insert the motor into the motor housing, attach the motor wires, and secure th motor in the housing with the endcap/radiator from the old pistol grip by screwing it into the holes at the bottom of the grip.
-Next slide the motor plate into the channel so that it looks like the pictures above.
-Slide the butt pad into it's registers in the back of the stock.
-Finally, insert 1/8 inch (3.175 mm) pins in to the holes marked with red circles.

description.text:
The AstroBox Touch has got me excited: Kickstarter or AstroPrint

So I made a case for a Raspberry Pi (3) and an Adafruit 3.5" TFT in a console style.

The Console consists of 3 parts: The Base, The Body and the Top or screen bezel. I used embedded nuts to bolt the parts together and for mounting the Raspberry Pi. The voids for the nuts are in the STL files, simply pause at the layer height and place the nuts then resume printing.

There are choices for the Base, some are enclosed and some an open frame. Both have options for a 40mm fan. The fan mounts below the Raspberry Pi, but there is an air duct that directs air flow over the top of the Pi as well.

The Body and Top should be rotated 45º to sit flat on your print bed. The BaseFanFrame should also be rotated to sit flat on the print bed for best results on the fan mounting surface.

After building your enclosure, follow this tutorial at Adafruit Learn to get it up and running.

When asked "Select project" choose option #2 and "Configure options manually".

Enjoy !

UPDATED

10/18/2017 Added: Revised PiBox, I made the wall with the power plug opening thinner to allow plug to seat better. Title: PiBoxTFTPiBoxPlugFriendly.stl

Added: I converted my SolidEdge part source files for those who would like to modify the parts into STEP (.stp) files which can be opened in a variety of software packages including AutoDesk's FREE Fusion 360.

11/14/2017 Added a Base for a 50mm blower fan with 20x15mm outlet. MUCH better airflow.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Silver

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

I used 0.2mm but 0.1 would be better.

Infill:

I used 30%.

Notes:

You will need:
(1) Raspberry Pi 2B or 3B
(1) Adafruit 3.5" TFT plus
(12) 2.5mm nuts
(12) 2.5mm Allen head bolts 6-10mm long

Optional:
(1) 40x10 mm axial fan OR 50mm blower fan with 20x15mm outlet.
(4) 3mm nuts
(4) 3mm bolts
I prefer nylon hardware for the fan, that can easily be snipped off to the desired length.

The Adafruit TFT plus 3.5" screen has mounting tabs on the PCB board. The mounting tab that sits over the Raspberry Pi's USB ports should be broken off for a proper fit. The mounting tabs are perforated for easy removal.

If anyone should ever want to turn the TFT backlight on/off it can be done through SSH at the terminal prompt by copy/paste:

sudo sh -c 'echo "0" > /sys/class/backlight/soc\:backlight/brightness'

to turn off, and:

sudo sh -c 'echo "1" > /sys/class/backlight/soc\:backlight/brightness'

to turn on.

Enjoy!

I used Solid Edge ST9 to design this case. I am excited for the AstroBox Touch, which inspired this design.

I use, and love AstroPrint !!!!

comments.text: I don't know that they are going to release the 5" for license, per a discussion with AstroPrint, as it was a Kickstarter limited edition... maybe. But don't worry, even if they don't I think I have that all figured out. They sent the STL's out to 5" Kickstarter supporters, and I already translated the STL's to solids and modified them. I like my RPi 3's to have a fan, as they run hotter than previous RPi's. Also, to print both parts with my current printer settings is over 30 hours. When I translated the STL's I did an assembly of the parts with a model of a RPi 3 and noticed their SD card cutout is off, so I adjusted that so you could actually get the card out. I made a couple different versions of the design, to try and reduce the +30 hour print. Their main body piece is mostly solid except for where the RPi sits, so I made a hollow shell version that reduces print time by about 8 hours. If you have AutoDesk's Fusion 360 (FREE) I can send you the assemblies.

comments.author: mettauk

comments.text: The nut voids are for 2.5mm standard nuts, not nyloc, and the layer height depends on your layer resolution being used. Most slicing software will let you look at the layer progression to determine which layer to pause at to insert the nuts before it prints over them. I usually put a few dabs of glue stick on the top of the nuts to help the filament stick when the nuts get printed over or spray the top of the nuts with hair spray, it works well also. I have also had good results not putting anything on the nuts, but it usually takes a few layers for it to get a good solid print on them.

description.text:
I am one of the few people who bought a Samsung Galaxy Player 5.0.
It replaced my Zune. haha
It's the size of a cell phone, but without cellular.
It's like a 5" tablet. It has a memory card and I use it to watch movies and videos on the planes when I travel. It's small and travels well.

I have a little stand for it that will sit on the drop down tray, but I wanted a way to hold it up higher.
I noticed that the little latch that holds the drop down tray up, has a hook built into it.
I designed and printed this holder for it. I think it will work but I haven't actually tried it yet. This is a work in progress.
I made one for my Player. And I made 2 more, one for my Samsung Galaxy S6 with a cover, and without a cover. I use my phone to take these pictures, so I don't have any pictures of my phone in the bracket.

If anyone likes this and wants one for your phone, measure it very carefully and send me the dimensions. I'll add it to the "thing".

For example, I measured my S6 at
142mm long
70mm wide
7mm thick

with a cover on my S6 measures
150mm long
76mm wide
12mm thick

I printed this using my standard ABS settings.
215 nozzle
100 bed
0.2 layer
50% infill

Technically speaking, my Sigma 70-200 f2.8 APO DG HSM is a second generation version of the lens. Visually the first gen had a different texture to the focus and zoom rings (like this: http://www.dyxum.com/images/Lenses/141/141_1.jpg). The second and third generation lenses look identical, though the mis-named HSM-II (third gen) version had different optics and added macro capability. You can see the second gen lens in my pic and the third gen pic in this review: http://www.the-digital-picture.com/Reviews/Sigma-70-200mm-f-2.8-DG-HSM-II-Macro-Lens-Review.aspx

Why this explanation? Because the lens hood from the latest generation of this lens DOES NOT FIT the older version(s) of the lens!

I had lost my lens hood while doing a photo shoot at car show, and although I bought a new one directly from Sigma, the new one never fit correctly. Even though Sigma swore up and down that it'd fit it very obviously didn't. Initially I thought it was a wear issue on the lens itself but looking closer it was obvious that although the filter size remained the same, the hood mount was about 1.5 millimeters larger on the new hood, so the hood never engaged properly on the lens.

If you elect to download manyjanos's files, the change that needs to be done is to change the x and y dimensions from 99.99mm to 97.5mm. That small change is all that's necessary to get the hood to fit correctly on the second gen version of the lens. I added the dimples to make it easier to visually see when the lens hood was aligned properly on the lens.

No matter the case, to completely finish this lens hood, you should give it a light sanding and then apply two coats of Rust-Oleum Truck Bed Coating Black Spray Paint (http://www.homedepot.com/p/Rust-Oleum-Automotive-15-oz-Truck-Bed-Coating-Black-Spray-Paint-248914/202097787) to prevent any light reflections from the material itself. That and it'll better match the rest of the lens too. For bonus points add a dab of white paint into the dimples.

I take the code of msdevstep and add some parametrer to make ir more customizable.

Blade ends, central cilinder, the cone in the base, etc,
Also the blade shape is not a cube anymore.

I used it to transform an standard radial computer fan into a centrifugal blower.

All the designs that I found are nor complete or have a lot of troubles to print.

I print it with PLA at 200 C, bed 60, and a very important thing isminimize OOZE, If you dont the blades will not be "clean".

My ooze prevention settings in my Repetier configuration is:

1-Start every layer at random point
2-ooze prevention . It shake the noozle when translate to other point
3-Z-lift elevate 0.1mm until travel.
4-Reduce a little your printing speed , and take care about extrusion.

see http://manual.slic3r.org/expert-mode/fighting-ooze for more detail

All theese setting are in printer tab ar slickr3 prusa edition.

I hope,you found this usefull.

This is to be used with wooden dowels (purchase from any hardware store, I got mine from Home Depot). The diameter of the dowels were 12.1mm and the approximate length I cut them dowels to was 550mm.

You'll have to print them with support and I recommend you print them standing on their side for maximum strength. It also gives you more than enough room to print 4 at the same time when they are standing on their side.

Printed on a heavily modded Monoprice Maker Select i3 v2 with Solutech white filament.

description.text:
This is an adapter for a Light & Motion Taz bicycle light, to fit a GoPro mount.

Here's the Taz light:
http://www.lightandmotion.com/choose-your-light/taz

Print with 100% infill, and 2 shells to make it pretty much solid, to maximize strength.

It requires a M3-.50x12 (metric) bolt. Obtain a M3-.50x12, 2mm hex bolt. This longer bolt provides more mating threads with the light, and also allows for a thicker part at the mounting hole, making it stronger overall.

I preferred the 2mm hex bolt head, because bicycle tools typically have a 2mm allen key. You may prefer a philips, flathead, or other variant.

The Taz light is mounted upside down, with this longer mounting screw. I found that the original Taz mounting screw was too short to give me confidence that it's bolting surface area and clamp-able thickness of PLA would hold up over bumps and jolts the bike experienced on the road.

Note: originally I didn't print with 100% infill, and the adapter broke over the first big bump my bike hit. I've ridden dozens of miles with the 100% infill part, over very poor pavement, and it's held the light just fine. Update 12/10/2017: I've now ridden a few hundred miles with it, and it's holding up fine.

Github
https://github.com/thrasher/light-and-motion-taz-gopro

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator Mini

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Use 2 shells and 100% infill. Print with the GoPro mount's legs facing up. Supports shouldn't be needed, but it depends on your slicer.

Clean off any raft or supports with a knife. Use a flat file or sandpaper to insure the mating surface for the light is flat and free of support material. Use a hand-drill to even out the two holes with appropriately sized drill bits.

title: Tarot 680 Pro Mounting Hooks for Camera / Battery Rails
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I needed two more of the mounting hooks you get when you purchase a set of these TL68B14 Battery Mounting Plate (Two hooks). After ordering 3 sets from 3 suppliers and waiting over two weeks I decided to design a replacement I could print at home.

There are two version, Standard and Small. This is to take account a different grommet sizes and there is not much difference in both. The small one just squeezes the grommet a bit more.

You will need 4 of these to fit two rails to the bottom of the Tarot 680Pro, and for each you will need a bulkhead 12mm rubber grommet (see picture for full measurements), and two M3 nut and bolts.

Can be used side by side with original hooks if required.

Designed with Fusion360.
EDIT: Added the f3d files so others can edit the design if their grommets are not the exact same size as mine.

Happy Flying!

50%

Notes:

Lay flat on the print bed so that the layer joints are opposite to the weight that is will hold.

Supporting will be required, for me it was best as 23% with some separation from the part for easy cleaning and to make the grommet space smooth.

I used ABS for strength.

author: Cool3dModeling

description.text:
These solar eclipse sunglasses are your ticket to watching the next two total solar eclipses in 2017 and 2024 as well as partial solar eclipses. Size them up or down to your according to your needs.

These were modeled after the early 1980s "robot sunglasses" that were popular at the time. They were also known as "Devo sunglasses" which was a popular band at that time since they wore similar sunglasses and later by a more recent band called The Phenomenauts. You can see them being worn in the 1983 music video, "No Tengo Dinero," by the Italian band, Righeira, and in the 1997 music video, "Everlong," by the Foo Fighters. You can also see them being worn in the 1980s film, "Sixteen Candles."

These were oversized for complete coverage over the eyes and for those who wear glasses. The black 3d printed model was sliced with Cura, 15% infill, and support. The pics show it printed showing the area of support, supports removed, and the solar film installed.

The solar film can either be two layers of mylar or solar filter film used for telescopes which you can purchase at your local astronomy supply shop or online at Amazon. This was cut to size slightly larger than the viewing area and taped or glued into place. The best adhesive for this application is Goop brand or Elmer's Stix-All mult-purpose adhesive.

I have two basic versions - a plain one and one with 3d graphics (2017 and 2024 eclipses).

comments.text: Awesome thanks for the upload.  the $5 mylar sheets i got (intended for gardening) take at least three layers to get to the 'can't see my hand in front of my face' effect that should hopefully be safe-ish for short periods.
comments.author: macelius

comments.text: Yes, two or three layers depending on the mylar you are using.
comments.author: macelius

comments.text:
Printed these in ABS on a airwolf 3D printer and they came out great. Suggestions for improving the design:
1.) thicken the bottom rail and add a nose piece contour (keep the lense opening mostly rectangular)
2.) create a recess for the film to sit in
2a.) maybe a two piece design so that the lense material can be sandwiched between them, and the plastic printed pieces snapped/glued together. The mylar seems hard to glue in. Got glue on the lense material trying to place it.
comments.author: CypressVH

comments.text: Good improvements.  I was thinking of creating a two piece design to sandwich the lens material between, but I decided to forgo it and go with the single piece and simply use adhesive to keep it attached.  The adhesive is Goop brand multi-purpose glue.  Elmer's Stix-All works quite well, too.

description.text:
The project consist to reuse the table spool holder to convert them to a wall spool holder.

The materials i used are:

  • the original spool holder frame
  • 4 printed support
  • 1 threaded bar
  • 1 aluminium tube
  • 4 14 mm original spool holder nuts
  • 4 wall fisher screw
  • 4 (15mm x M3) screws

The four printed parts fit perfectly with the spool holder frame , they are fixed to the frame by four (15mm x M3) screws. The printed parts are used to fit the spool holder frame to the wall, they are fixed by four wall fischer screw.
The threaded rod is positioned in the original frames holes, is more lenght to the original to host up to five spool.
Above the threaded rod there is an aluminium tube that increase spool sliding.
Finally the 2 spool holder frames are fixed to the bar by four 14 mm nuts.

A simple over-door coat hanger. You just need some rigid wire and optionally something to cover that wire with in order to finish it. I forget the exact type of wire that I used, but any sort of stiff wire that can fit through the holes should work. For the covering I used the outer sheath of some cheap para-cord. I have put a lot of weight on mine, and it has shown no sign of collapsing, cracking or bending.

Cut an appropriate length of wire; bend it to fit through the slots and holes in the body. Make the appropriate bend so that it fits over the door it is going to be used with. I bent the cut ends so that they met and overlapped on the back side of the door. I slid the covering sleeve over one side, then twisted the wire together and slid the sleeve back over the twisted together section in order to hide the joint. You can always re-do the bends to optimize the fit.

author: dutchmogul

description.text:
Made in 123D Design

I designed this mount because I had difficulty adjusting the sensor height as with the stock mount the rear nuts on the sensor screws were inaccessible. This became a problem when calibrating my Z offset or swapping filaments as I would need to remove the extruder fan to make sure the filament got in the hole.

This design lets me easily adjust the height of the sensor. Something I find myself doing with some frequency when I dial in my Z offset and such.

It is designed to fit the TronXY P802M but will likely fit many variants.

You can probably print it at up to .3mm resolution and at least 10% infill with no problems.

Printer:

TronXY P802M

Notes:

Feel free to try higher resolutions and lower infill if you need to.
You also should not need supports as the over hangs are quite small.
Just make sure it is oriented standing on the top side.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
KICKSTARTER ALERT- Hey, everyone. We've just launched a kickstarter campaign for our friend Jeff Bowers' competitive card game, Alien Architects!

"There are exceptional monuments, buildings, and statues on Earth that have left archaeologists wondering for millennia about their origins and construction. The Great Pyramids of Egypt, the Moai of Easter Island, Stonehenge of England, the Ball of Twine of Kansas; could early civilizations of humans have designed and built these with limited technology and knowledge? Or is it possible (even probable) that we, on this planet, have been receiving help from more advanced cultures from other worlds? In Alien Architects you take on the role of an extraterrestrial who has traveled across the galaxy to compete with other aliens to build monuments on earth throughout human history. Collect or steal resources, blueprints, and technology in order to prove that you are the greatest builder in the universe. And why not have some fun with the humans while you’re here?"

This miniature represents an alien similar to the one on the cover of the game and a printed version from Shapeways (like the models shown) is available as a pledge reward.

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...)

Enjoy!

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/k3PddLXaL4C

Abracadabra! Perform a magic coin piercing trick and amaze your family and friends. The eight solid pins pierce the solid coin eight times yet the coin comes back out of the container undamaged! See the demo video at http://youtu.be/96b9ElucVW0 . This project is sure to amaze your kids and help reassure your spouse that the 3D printer is a true household asset! Also see Thing 25344, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:25344. Enjoy! 11 June 2012: Add missing OpenSCAD source file
11 June 2012: Ran the bottom piece through Netfabb
14 June 2012: Determined cause of problems for Slic3r; uploaded new top & bottom .stl file and new .scad file

Download the three .stl files, slice them, and print them. For maximum impact, print the coin and pins a contrasting color from that used for the top and bottom of the enclosure. Note that I sliced using 100% fill and 4 shells. The pins may print better with a raft. You can use the supplied OpenSCAD file to regenerate the container and pins to your specifications. For example, to a size which will work with your local currency. To perform the trick,
  • Let your audience inspect the coin and pins. Check your sleeves, etc., etc.
  • Place the coin into the bottom of the container.
  • Place the top cover over the bottom. The two pieces have alignment tabs to ensure correct orientation of the pin holes between the top and bottom.
  • Begin by "piercing" the coin with a pin through one of the outermost four holes. Do NOT start with any of the four inner holes. By using one of the outer holes, the coin is tipped upwards and out of the way of the pins.
  • Place the remaining seven pins through the remaining seven holes.
  • Show your audience that the pins move: push one from the bottom and see the pin's head rise.
  • Remove the pins. Unlike in the video, things will be a little quieter if you remove the outer pins first: that way the coin only shifts down a little at a time. If you make the last pin an outer pin, then the coin will have farther to drop.
  • Give a gentle magic "tap" and/or shake, maybe saying "presto" or "abracadabra" at the same time. This is really to make sure that the coin has dropped back down.
  • Re-open the container, showing the audience that the coin is still there and undamaged with no holes.

Tämä väline kääntää noin 8mm kapean päärmeen.
Käännä malli tulostusta varten kuvan osoittamaan asentoon, kapea pää ylöspäin.

Käyttöohje:

  1. Asettele kankaan reuna valmiiksi päärmäyskikkareen sisään ja käännä päärme alkuun, auttaa jos kiinnität paikalleen esim. nuppineulalla.
  2. Kiinnitä maalarinteipillä suoraan paininjalan eteen
  3. Ompele! Ohjaa kangasta reunaan kuvan osoittamalla tavalla.
  4. Paksuista saumakohdista kikkare ei selviydy, joten ennen niitä kikkare kannattaa irroittaa ja laittaa sitten takaisin.

In English:
This tool makes a 8mm narrow hem.
Before printing, rotate the model so that it is in the position shown by the image, narrow head up.

Manual:

  1. Put the edge of the fabric inside the päärmäyskikkare, and attach the beginning of the hem e.g. with a pin.
  2. Attach the päärmäyskikkare in front of presser foot e.g. with a masking tape.
  3. Sew! Guide the fabric as shown in the picture.
  4. Joints may get stuck in the päärmäyskikkare, so it is better to remove it before a joint and then put it back.

Here is a box and two lids decorated with mazes. Joe Wingbermuehle has written maze generators in many languages - http://joewing.net/projects/maze/ -; a nice project worth a look. The program in fortran, maze.f90, is easily converted to make input for openSCAD's surface command. Output from maze.f90 and openSCAD code for the box and lids are included.
To change maze.f90 to make input for openSCAD's surface command change maze.f90's output symbols from '[]' and '  ' to '4 4 4 4 ' and '2 2 2 2 ' and output each line four times.

title: T4bee Microcopters Parakeet Multicopters for 2" - 4" propellers and 110X - 160X motors

description.text:
The Parakeet ecosystem is made for 20x20mm sized hardware and able to fit various motors, prop sizes. It is centered around a very low profile build and the Runcam Swift Micro. All bottom plates are fully interchangable, meaning, you only need to unscrew the 4 standoff scews and your FC stack screws and plonk the entire top onto different sized or shaped mainplate.

Update: Everything in Carbon Fibre on Armattan Production here: https://armattanproductions.com/pages/shop_product_grid/985

On Rcgroups: https://www.rcgroups.com/forums/showthread.php?2968166-Parakeet-Ecosystem-Quads-Hexas-2-4-100-190

Video of the parakeet 158 maiden:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bcDd0lof55w

comments.text: You should design a parakeet-type hexacopter frame but for dys se1806 motors, 4 inch props, micro swift and 36x36mm boards. It'll make a sick 4 inch screamer that can keep up with a 5 inch racer.
comments.author: MajorProblems

comments.text: that's basically a complete redesign ;) with current hardware, I don't think there's actually any need to go 30.5x30.5 anymore. 20x20 is the future. Most 1806 still have 12mm diameter mounting holes, so you can put that on these frames if you so desire. I will indeed probably make a 4" hexa for this as well, but that will have to wait a bit.
comments.author: MajorProblems

description.text:
Update 2018-03-05: I've added a new thicker shim piece (Filament_Runout_Sensor_piece_thick.stl). It's meant to be used with a limit switch that has the metallic lever removed (squeeze and twist it off with pliers). It's highly recommended over the original piece.
My limit switch started to wear out and became slightly unpredictable, but removing the level and using the thicker shim is excellent! Shame I didn't think of it in the first pace.

A filament runout sensor using a simple micro-switch that attaches directly to the Titan extruder.
As opposed to simpler designs, it allows the filament to be inserted from either direction, meaning the printer can push out the filament during a M600 Filament Change operation.
(Also includes a viewport to watch the filament, for no real reason)

For 1.75mm filament!

Hopefully the tolerances will work for you. I had to revise the sizes several times while prototyping, but it's now perfect on my end.

Refer your firmware's documentation (here's Marlin) on how to configure the sensor.

Extras you'll need:

  • A micro limit switch / endstop (KW-1 2A? I used a spare I had from my TEVO Tarantula kit: about 13mm wide, 6mm thick)
  • 2x M2 screws + nuts to secure the switch

Printer:

TEVO Tarantula i3

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

Any

Notes:

Print the main body upright with the flat (windowed) bottom on the bed. No need for supports.

I recommend printing the smaller piece sideways with supports, you'll get a smoother surface on the arc which makes the filament's job easier.

1. Insert the small padding piece into the main body.
  2. Slide in the limit switch and screw it in place using the M2 screws. The switch should not click yet.
  3. Test the sensor by pushing filament through. You should hear the switch should click.
    • If you do not hear the switch toggle: the pad piece is likely too thick. Unassemble and file down the pad-piece from the flat bottom so it won't trigger the switch in the base state.
  4. Jam the sensor to the Titan input. Just like that. It should fit snugly.
  5. Attach the wires to your board and configure your firmware (I changed the FIL_RUNOUT_PIN to use the X+ connector, pin 2)

Enjoy your new automated M600 capabilities!

comments.text: Hi, could you share your f360 model or made a version for 3mm filament? Thanks!
comments.author: ajtudela

comments.text:
Sorry, no. I don't have 3mm filament, and the whole thing is designed around that 1.75mm size. Using 3mm in a titan doesn't leave room/require the guide plug, either, so securing the sensor housing would require more design.
The thing is essentially a hollowed out cube with a hole through it + screwholes for the limit switch, so it shouldn't take you longer than an hour to design (provided you have your measurements down), plus an hour or two to properly tune the fit. Less effort than adjusting every part of the existing design, which would already be there if I deemed it good enough for public eyes.
comments.author: ajtudela

comments.text: Just what I need. Could you please elaborate on the firmware change and post the code that works for you ? Thank you so much !
comments.author: Denis56

comments.text:
I raise EXTRUDE_MAXLENGTH from 200 to 600 (if you're on Bowden, you'll want the 600mm movement), so the M600 can retract the filemament fully.
Follow the Marlin docs and uncomment the //#define ADVANCED_PAUSE_FEATURE line in Configuration_adv.h, adjust the M600 block to what you'd like (I'm going with extended timeout, just two beeps and PARK_HEAD_ON_PAUSE).
Since I wanted to use the X+ endstop pin, I changed FIL_RUNOUT_PIN to 2 in pins_RAMPS.h.

UPDATE 12/29/2012 Some user decided to put this case up for sale and did not pay any attention to the licensing of this item. I am removing the stls. UPDATE 9/20/2012
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:30572 A new thing has been released to replace this one. There have been many complaints about the rca port being off by just a hair so this has been resolved in the new parametric model not made in Sketchup like this one was.

Print RasPiCase-Bottom.stl and fit the Raspberry Pi into the case SD card slot first. It should be a snug fit. Printing just the bottom is a great base for hacking away at the RasPi. For a fully enclosed case print RasPiCase-Bottom.stl AND RasPiCase-Top.stl. Fit the RasPi in the case SD Card slot first and fit lid on top. For larger bots you can print RasPiCase.stl which contains both the top and the bottom of the case in 1 plate. I've been printing this with a .35 nozzle at .2 layer height with 2 perims and .2 fill. Doesn't even really seem to need a heat bed to print. UPDATE
I've added a vented top to the case for those concerned with cooling issues.

title: FT-5 No More Tears Anti-Tangle Chip Brush Filament Guide

description.text:
During a large print my new spool of filament started to unravel and tangle. Rather than risk waking up the next morning to a failed print, I MacGuyvered a makeshift solution using a 1" chip brush and some zip ties. This thing is a more elegant version of the same idea.

The filament is guided through the brush's bristles, giving it just enough resistance that it can be easily pulled out as the printers extruder requires, but doesn't allow the filament to get pushed back out towards the spool causing the dreaded tangle.

This was designed to fit a Folgertech FT-5, but may also work for other printers built from 2020 extrusion. It gets mounted to the top of the printer using an 8mm M3 screw and t-nut from the under-side. A standard 1" chip brush head should fit into the opening, and can be secured using another 8mm M3 screw or two. Filament should exit your spool from under the arm, run through the brush bristles, through the two loops and then into your extruder.
Here's the No More Tears advanced prototype in the field.

title: TronXY X1 Y Belt Tensioner
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The original "tensioner" that comes with the X1 is rubbish, and was difficult to adjust.

I also have the TronXY X3, and printed a tensioner made by user idig3d. His design is an elegant solution, and so i took inspiration from his design, and modelled from scratch a tensioner to work with X1.

I have designed the tensioner to work with idig3d's end cap, knob and bracket. I have included them here, but to be clear, they are not my design. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2020468/#files

I also highly recommend downloading and printing the above link for idig3d's x belt tensioner for the x belt of your x1.

It works very well, and is very secure with 6 screws, but you really only need 4 or less.

Reuses existing bits. Only needs an M5x25 screw and an M5 nut.

Printer:

TronXY X3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20

Notes:

Recommend printing a brim of 10-20 with a 0mm offset from part is you have issues with bed adhesion.

I didnt use supports when i printed this, but if you are unsure i would print with supports.

Only extra parts need are an M5x25 screw and an M5 nut.

Reuse the existing screws and drop-in t-nuts. Slide it over the 2020 extrusion.

Thread the M5 screw onto the bracket until it's tight. Reuse the carriage washers, washers, bearing, M5 screw and nut and reassemble the pulley in the new bracket. Tighten just enough to hold together.

title: Helios 44M-4 Nikon Infinity Focus mod parts

description.text:
About two and a half years ago I've purchased a Helios 44M-4 for my Nikon D3200 body. It was my first prime, cheap, but with beautifuly interesting swirly bokeh. Yet the main flaw was that the lens cannot focus to infinity on a Nikon body.

I've started modding the lens back then, by replacing the M42 screw mount with a Nikon F adapter. I could get about 2 meters plus focus distance but it wasn't infinity.
I also had to create a plastic part that kept pressed the aperture enable lever inside the lens. It was cut out from a CD case and it did a great job.
To get infinity focus I had to unscrew the backward lens part (closest to the sensor) by 0,9mm, to let the focus plane aligned with the sensor.

Since I got my 3D printer (6 days ago) creating parts is much easier than before.

I've measured everything, and modelled the parts that needed, to convert my Helios to a infinity focus lens on a Nikon body.

On the attached pictures you can see where you have to place the different parts. The last image is a quick test snaphot with the lens focused to infinity.

I didn't attached disassemble images / video because you can find many on Youtube.

I've ordered the aluminium Nikon adapter from ebay for about $1. (M42 to Nikon F adapter).

Unfortunately I don't know if it works with other Helios 44M models.

I hope you find this design useful.

Sorry for my bad english.

Close your eyes and picture a mountain. Chances are you are visualizing the Matterhorn. Towering high in the Swiss alps, it is the world's most iconic peak. She is not as high as some, or as steep, and comfortable climbers huts dot the slopes. But the Matterhorn has killed more than twice as many climbers as Mt Everest. You can watch a video tutorial on how to make your own mini mountains at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bzwybr65I9o This is part of my series of "collectible mountains". All the models in this series are rendered at 1:100000. The model represents an area 10km x 10km. The bottom of the model sits at sea level so the different mountains can be accurately compared. Have you even wondered just how much bigger Everest is than Mt Shasta? Now you can hold them both in your hands and compare. Complete instructions on how to make models from digital elevation data can be found on my blog at http://www.the3dprintedfuture.com/shapespeare/?p=1

Cubo de calibração de extrusion multiplier ou multiplicador de extrusão.
Este cubo deve ser feito com 0% de infill, com 3 paredes de contorno e sem nenhuma layer de topo. Fazer este cubo 5 vezes, alternado apenas o parâmetro extrusion multiplier no fatiador, utilizando 0,92 0,94 0,96 0,98 e 1,00 para após a impressão avaliar as medidas dos mesmos nas paredes e verificar qual deles bate com a medida da largura da sua extrusão x 3. Por exemplo se a largura da sua extrusão for 0,5 logo o cubo impresso que tiver 1,5 mm de espessura (0,5x3) será o fator de extrusão correto para o material que está sendo usado na sua máquina. Lembrando que é para este rolo de material. Este valor pode mudar conforme o rolo de material, ou conforme o tipo de material utilizado no momento.

author: Vaan

description.text:
This is a ratchet locker differential, used in some 4x4 vehicles.
It's minded to be a "brother" for the Torsen Limited Slip Differential from @Pizzachef (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1722483), witch is also a remix from @Unotre (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:356169).

You will need to print original pieces from @Pizzachef to complete.

Print 2 units:
Part3, Part4b, and Part5

For this Thing, you will also need:
6xDin 912 (M3x10mm Cilindrical allen screw)
25mm 1.75diam filament cut to join central hub with its axis.
Some grease (I used solid baseline)
2x 20mm Springs from old pens (softer, better)

08/08/2017 Updated minor changes to fit properly to the base.

respetar la altura de capa

author: FutureStarsLab

description.text:
In Israel, to use a shopping cart in the supermarket, you need to deposit 5 Shekel coin in the cart. This project prints a ring with the external dimensions of the 5 Shekels so you can use it instead of the real coin, you can keep it in your wallet and never find yourself without one.

In the last update, I added a coin holder that can be attached to your key-chain, and in which the coin is inserted in a slot so it can be easily taken out or in.

The openSCAD model contains both items ready for parallel printing, yet the stl files offer the choice to print both together, or each separately for a cleaner generation one by one.

title: EiiiCooler for Anet A8
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
The EiiiCooler is a cooler for your cold end and extruder motor of the Anet A8.

[RECOMMENDED RADIAL FANS]
www.banggood.com/3Pcs-3D-Printer-12V-DC-50mm50mm-Blow-Radial-Cooling-Fan-p-1121554.html

You'll get much higher airflow by using a radial fan through the heatsink as well as into the extruder gear area compared to what the axial fan can provide.

Top reasons why to use the EiiiCooler:
1) You're certain to get a very high flow-rate of cold air across the hotend heatsink!
2) You'll get more airflow into the extruder gear area!
3) No more fiddling with those annoying white plastic spacers anymore during maintenance, they're not needed anymore.

Please note that this is not a 3D performance output booster in any means, but it does solve some potential issues the default setup has. E3D team has reported that almost half of problems reported on their hotends is due to insufficient cooling of the coldend.

[REQUIRED HARDWARE]
1 pcs M4x20 screw (or longer)
1 pcs M4 nut (or locknut)
1 pcs 51x51x15 mm radial fan (Look at Delta BFB0512HH for dimensions datasheet)

[DONATIONS]
If you find that the item improve your daily life, consider supporting the designer by sending a tip.
Click "TIP DESIGNER" here.

description.text:
After playing with these walls for a bit I've modified the design a little. You can find v2 here https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2477128
They're the same scale, just a little more modular for the sake of future development.

My sons and I have really enjoyed the 15mm scale models created by dutchmogul and we wanted some modular walls, in the same scale, that we could use to make things more fun.
https://www.thingiverse.com/dutchmogul/collections/15mm-scale-miniature-gaming

The walls with the stands are 35mm tall, matching the height of dutchmogul's models. They're 1, 2 and 3 segments long, with each segment being 20mm long. This makes the wall segments 20x35, 40x35 and 60x45. The walls are actually 34mm tall and the stand adds 1mm height. The stands should clip on and hold just fine or you can glue them.

This is my first attempt at creating my own models for 3D printing so please give me feedback on how I might improve these. This is just the beginning and I plan on making more styles, including corner pieces. I'd also like to make some modular building pieces that work with these, like floor in various shapes that the walls can clip in to.

comments.text: I printed mine with no support. As the round portion of the bottom of the bowl starts to move upward from the print bed, it does sag just a little, but it still came out pretty clean with no support at all. I used 3 solid surfaces top and bottom, with a layer height of 0.25mm (so the top and bottom were 0.75mm). This will seal the top surface better. 20% infill should be fine. I used a slower print speed of 60 mm/sec. PrototypeAsia was correct, however. After about a week of use, the water bowl did start to leak. After letting it dry out for another week or so, I sealed the inside of the bowl with a thin layer of 2-part epoxy, and now it is water tight.

comments.author: TheKre8Group

comments.text: I always had problems with porosity of XY planes.
comments.author: marcsulf

comments.text: When I first started printing a couple of years ago, my prints sometimes had this problem.  I found that it was a combination of printing too fast at too cold a temperature, or not having the filament diameter dialed in properly.  Any of these problems can lead to the extruded volume flow rate being too low, which leads to porosity.  Make sure you have an accurate measurement of the filament diameter (within +/- 5%), and print slow.  Also you need to find that happy temperature hot enough that your extruder can keep up with the print speed, but not so hot that overhangs and bridges start drooping.  Using a fan (Recommended for PLA) can have a massive impact on these numbers, too.  You have to dial these numbers in for every different filament, too, since the pigments in each one change their visco-elastic behavior as well as their glass transition temperature (and with ABS, there are also a wide range of Acrylonitrile, butadiene, and styrene ratios used which also plays a major role).  And if you change your print speed, you will need to change your extrusion temperature to compensate.
comments.author: TheKre8Group

title: TronXY X3, X3S, X1 Laser Engraving and Quick Connect Tooling

description.text:
Update: 08/11/17 I added variations that allow for cable chain support

I decided I want to the option to quickly change tooling heads on my X3 and I also wanted to incorporate laser engraving functionality on the printer. These designs allow me to do all of this. Please refer to the video for a tutorial on laser engraving as well as the general setup of the components.

Please note for the wiring setup I have implemented that you do this at your own risk as there is a chance you could melt the connect on at the hot end for the heater element if you are not careful. The wiring setup can be done any number of ways and I give one example in the video. Also, when laser engraving please do so in a well-ventilated area as there are quite a bit of fumes generated and use all precautions such as protective eye wear when dealing with lasers.

Check out the video for more information:
https://youtu.be/CWTCqT_LUfs

Also note that due to the Hot end assemblies on the X3, X3S, and X1 being identical it is possible to implement this modification including laser functionality on the X1 and X3S 3D Printer

Sun Vision mount for GoPro.

This is a bracket to hold three 5mm LEDs to light up the build platform around the extruder tip for a Printrbot Simple 2014 (with the aluminum extruder and the fan with hood.. I used 3 5mm white LEDs wired in parallel through a 5.6 ohm resistor to 5 volts on the EXP1 OR EXP2 connector on the printer board. If you wanted to connect to 12v, you would need a 15 ohm resistor to feed the three LEDs in parallel. Alternatively You could wire the LEDs in series through a 12 ohm resistor to 12v. Enjoy...
Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/d3VqfLl17F3

What you need:
  • This thing printed
  • 3 x 5mm white LEDs preferably wide angle
  • 1 x resistor (value depends on voltage source- 5.6 ohom for 5v or 15 ohm for 12v)
  • 1 x 2 position 2.54mm female header connector (or other connector if you will connect to 12v someplace).
  • Extra wire, small diameter heat shrink tubing.
  • soldering iron, solder and skills
  • Print it.
  • Stick in 3 LEDs
  • Wire the LEDs either in parallel or serial. (Use parallel if you plan to power from 12v). I use the clippings from other components and heat shrink over one of the wires to connect my LEDs because they stay where you tuck them.
  • Tuck the LED wires into the channels in the brackets. Use heat shrink to prevent shorting.
  • Wire in power to the LEDs. The lead can either come off the corner where the bracket mounts, OR off the corner where the writing is on the bracket.
  • 5v can be found on the EXP1 or EXP2 connectors. See the schematic for you revision of the board to find it.
  • Print with light on the print tip!!
    • Notes: Hot glue can be used to secure the LEDs and wires in the bracket channels as required.

Starting from a common visualization of a Klein bottle - turned upside down - it's possible to see how the surfaces can be deformed to make a mug one can actually drink from - even though you'd really be drinking from the "outside" surface of the object. But, for a Klein bottle, there is only one surface anyway - "outside" and "inside" are really the same! Follow through the hollow handle to the "inside". For more info, and the source of my inspiration see http://www.kleinbottle.com/ Note that this is a 3D model of what's really a 4D object.

If you have very good bridging with your printer, these models can be printed in one piece.  Personally, I didn't have the nerve to do that, so I separated each one into bottom and top chambers that can be separately printed and glued together.  
There's an advantage to two sections.  For the "equal chambers" model, you can add potpourri to the bottom before gluing, allowing for a treat for both the sense of taste and that of smell, as the scent travels out through the hollow handle. I hope to add dried rose buds to one for a bit of "wine and roses" later today!  This would prove you've got a 3D (so, pseudo) Klein bottle mug even when printed in an opaque color.  
The other model, when filled with a liquid in the bottom chamber (after gluing - I used a food syringe to overcome the airlock) acts like a barometer. And, the top can hold pens & pencils without them getting wet.  
Useful applications for a 4D object printed in 3D!  
CAUTION: Quick prints may require coating with a food safe acrylic varnish to prevent leaks.

Will those lasercut wood parts stick together? No. In order to prevent this in the future I made this little Test. I expect the actual tolerance to be depending on the lasercutter but failed to find detailed information. So an experiment might enlighten the most, I thought.

I will be designing a LMS 3990 CNC machine and could not find any files online. So I took apart the XY axis of my machine and got measurements. The Z axis was not taken apart so it is lacking some details but there should be more than enough information there to make your own cnc machine.

title: Ceiling junction box for pendant lamps (v2)

description.text:
A small junction box for the ceiling. I use it to hide the cables and screw terminal (luster terminal) that come out of the ceiling. This allows me to move the hanging lamp (pendant lamp) away from the hole in the ceiling while hiding its ugly connectors.

This is version 2 which features bigger cable holes (not visible in video and uploaded pictures but in rendered STL file).

Cable hole in lid (ceiling contact): 10 mm
Cable hole in body: 5,6 mm
Diameter: 100 mm
Height: 38 mm

Video:
https://youtu.be/qc448HdpeAg

description.text: This is an update to my original Aldi/Einhel Breakout adapter, which now has a Makita battery adapter & Makita Terminal block built into 1 print . Its now thinner & smaller in overall dimensions & doesn't require a Makita contact block , as everything is built into the model. Connectors are inserted into the printed slots & a solder connection is all that's needed to keep them in place .
